questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketionuria with normal phenyl alanine hydroxylase levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dihydrobiopterine reductase:

  • Phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase can be caused by a deficiency of dihydrobiopterin reductase, which helps in the conversion of dihydrobiopterin to tetrahydrobiopterin. This leads to the failure of the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C do not cause phenylketonuria.

questions.text: A patient presents with dermatitis, dementia, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Niacin

Explanation:

The Clinical scenario of Dermatitis, Dementia and Cognitive decline suggests Niacin deficiency (Pellagra)

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia.

Thiamine (Option B) (Vitamin B1) deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Tryptophan (Option C) plays a crucial role in various metabolic processes. It serves as a precursor for Niacin (Vitamin B3) and Serotonin. Thus symptoms like mood alteration, decreased/increased appetite is also present.

Riboflavin (Option D) deficiency causes cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis and proliferation of bulbar conjunctival capillaries.

questions.text: Which of the following post-translational modifications is common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subunit aggregation

Explanation

  • Subunit aggregation refers to the assembly of protein subunits into a functional multimeric structure. This process is seen in hemoglobin, collagen, and immunoglobulins.

 

Hydroxylation (Option A): This is a post-translational modification involving the addition of hydroxyl groups to amino acids. While hydroxylation is important in collagen synthesis, it is not a common modification for hemoglobin and immunoglobulins.

Poly A tail addition (Option C): This is a post-transcriptional modification that involves adding a polyadenine tail to the 3' end of mRNA. It helps in mRNA stability and translation efficiency but does not pertain to the protein structures in question.

DNA mismatch repair (Option D): DNA mismatch repair is a genomic maintenance process that corrects errors in DNA replication. It is unrelated to protein post-translational modifications.

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit?

choices.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted
RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of time only

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Human cells can divide a finite number of times only.:

The hayflick limit, discovered by Dr. Leonard Hayflick, states that normal human cells have a finite capacity for replication.

  • Telomeres, protective caps at chromosome ends, shorten with each cell division due to incomplete DNA replication.
  • Shortened telomeres eventually lead to cellular senescence, preventing uncontrolled cell division and potential cancer.
  • Some cells, like stem cells and certain cancers, express telomerase, extending telomeres and bypassing the Hayflick limit.
  • In normal human cells, telomerase activity is limited, leading to replicative senescence.

The Hayflick limit, the maximum times cells can divide, is influenced by several factors:

  • Telomere Length: Shortening telomeres indicate reduced division capacity.
  • Telomerase Activity: Higher activity extends telomeres, bypassing the limit.
  • DNA Damage: Accumulated damage triggers senescence, limiting division.
  • Cellular Stress: Various stressors accelerate senescence, reducing the limit.
  • Genetic Factors: Variations affect telomere maintenance and DNA repair.
  • Environmental Factors: Lifestyle, pollutants, and stress impact cellular health, affecting the limit.

Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted (Option B): The Hayflick limit is not directly related to free radical oxidation levels.

Telomerase activity is unrestricted (Option C): Telomerase activity is typically restricted in normal human cells, unlike stem cells and certain cancers.

RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only (Option D): The Hayflick limit primarily involves telomere shortening, not RNA polymerase function.

questions.text: A female patient presented with pain and redness in the great toe. The serum uric acid level is 9.4mg/dl. The physician prescribed a drug for the treatment. Which of the following enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Xanthine oxidase

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes a female patient with pain and redness in the great toe, which suggests gout, a condition caused by elevated uric acid levels.
  • The patient's serum uric acid level of 9.4 mg/dl is above the normal range, indicating hyperuricemia, which can lead to the formation of uric acid crystals in the joints, causing pain and inflammation.
  • The physician has prescribed a drug that helps manage gout by reducing uric acid levels.
  • The drug prescribed is allopurinol, which is known to inhibit xanthine oxidase, the enzyme responsible for converting hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid.
  • By inhibiting xanthine oxidase, allopurinol decreases the production of uric acid, effectively managing gout by lowering uric acid levels in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Phosphoribosyl transferase (Option A): Involved in purine metabolism, but not the target of allopurinol.

Thymidylate synthase (Option B): Involved in DNA synthesis, not related to gout treatment.

Dihydrofolate reductase (Option D): Involved in folate metabolism, and inhibited by drugs like methotrexate, not relevant to gout treatment.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with poor feeding, vomiting, and lethargy. Laboratory studies show hyperammonemia and elevated levels of orotic acid in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency

Explanation:

The infant's symptoms and laboratory findings are highly suggestive of Type 2 Hyperammonemia, or Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) Deficiency.

  • Hyperammonemia type 2 is an X-linked deficiency caused by a defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase (this reaction occurs in mitochondria), which forms citrulline in the Krebs cycle.
  • Mothers with this condition may have hyperammonemia and avoid high-protein foods.
  • Elevated blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine glutamine levels are due to increased glutamine synthesis in response to high ammonia levels.
  • Orotic aciduria- Due to the channelling of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

Feature

Type 1 Hyperammonemia

Type 2 Hyperammonemia

Defective Enzyme

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS1) (Option A)

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mechanism

The inability to synthesize carbamoyl phosphate blocks the urea cycle.

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

Metabolic Consequences
  • Elevated ammonia and glutamate
  • Normal orotic acid and uracil
  • Low citrulline.
  • Elevated ammonia, glutamate, and glutamine.
  • High uracil and/or orotic acid (excess carbamoyl phosphate enters pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Normal citrulline.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms coincide with increased protein intake.
  • CNS: Lethargy, drowsiness, coma, Convulsions, vomiting, respiratory stimulation, hyperventilation.
  • Similar to Type 1.
  • Hepatomegaly.

 

  • Orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase deficiency (Option C): this is orotic aciduria (megaloblastic anaemia, growth retardation), but ammonia is normal.
  • Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency (Option D): causes hyperammonemia but with elevated citrulline/argininosuccinate, not orotic acid.
